groundtruth: Since your study is focused on evaluating the accuracy of a new diagnostic test, I would recommend classifying it as a Phase II study. This phase typically involves testing the efficacy and safety of new interventions or techniques.

For participant inclusion, you could consider stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or individuals who have passed the acute phase of myocardial infarction. The age requirement should be set at 18 years or older, and written informed consent is essential. Additionally, participants should have intermediate coronary lesions with diameter stenosis ranging from 30% to 80% as estimated by visual examination from coronary angiography.

Participants should be excluded if they are ineligible for diagnostic IVUS or FFR examination, have undergone prior coronary artery bypass grafting of the interrogated vessels, experienced myocardial infarction within 72 hours of coronary angiography, or have severe heart failure. Serum creatinine levels greater than 150 umol/L or glomerular filtration rates below 45 ml/kg/1.73 m2 should also be considered exclusions. Furthermore, individuals with allergies to the contrast agent or adenosine, life expectancy of less than 2 years, IVUS pullback that does not cover the entire lesion, or severe myocardial bridge in the interrogated vessel should be excluded from the study.

Based on the information you provided, I suggest having two study arms. The first arm will focus on pressure wire-based fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the participant group. The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic test: fractional flow reserve (FFR). This arm is necessary as FFR is a well-established standard reference for assessing the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis. By using pressure wire-based FFR as a comparison, we can evaluate the accuracy of the new diagnostic test, ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR).

The second study arm should involve participants who will undergo intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)-based ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR). The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic tests: ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS). This arm is important as it focuses on the new diagnostic test, UFR, which is the main intervention being evaluated in this trial. By combining UFR with IVUS, we aim to assess the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis in a more comprehensive manner. The use of IVUS will provide detailed imaging of the coronary vessels, enhancing the accuracy of UFR calculations.

groundtruth: The intervention involves the use of ICI201, which is an investigational drug being evaluated in this trial. It is a CAR-T cell therapy that specifically targets GPRC5D, a protein expressed on the surface of multiple myeloma cells. By targeting this protein, ICI201 aims to selectively kill multiple myeloma cells while sparing normal cells.

Certainly! The ICI201 CAR-T cell injection involves genetically modifying the patient's own T cells to express a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) that specifically targets GPRC5D. These modified CAR-T cells are then infused back into the patient's body. Once inside, they can recognize and destroy multiple myeloma cells that express GPRC5D. This personalized approach harnesses the patient's immune system to target and eliminate cancer cells.

Firstly, the participants in this arm will provide valuable data on molecular prognostic factors and resistance mechanisms to osimertinib in the adjuvant treatment of completely resected pIB-IIIA NSCLC with common EGFR mutations. Secondly, the collection of plasma ctDNA at various time points will allow us to monitor molecular events associated with relapse on or after osimertinib exposure, providing insights into the effectiveness of osimertinib and potential resistance mechanisms. Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) in monitoring renal function in hemodialysis patients. The study will compare the NIRS results with other clinical parameters such as urine output, GFR, and blood tests to determine the potential value of NIRS in detecting and predicting residual renal injury. The study will also evaluate the accuracy and reliability of NIRS in detecting residual renal injury compared to traditional methods.

-----------------
The study will be conducted in a single-center, prospective, observational study design. The study will include 100 hemodialysis patients who meet the inclusion criteria. The screening phase will last for 1 month, during which the patients will undergo baseline assessments of their renal function using NIRS, urine output, GFR, and blood tests. The follow-up phase will last for 3 months, during which the patients will undergo monthly assessments of their renal function using NIRS, urine output, GFR, and blood tests. The primary outcome measure will be the correlation between NIRS results and other clinical parameters in predicting residual renal injury. The secondary outcome measures will be the accuracy and reliability of NIRS in detecting residual renal injury compared to traditional methods.

The study will also compare the effects of the new treatment to a standard treatment, called a placebo procedure. The study will last for 12 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: the renal denervation group, the sham group, or the placebo group. Participants in the renal denervation group will undergo a renal denervation procedure, which involves using a catheter to deliver radiofrequency energy to the renal arteries. Participants in the sham group will undergo a sham procedure, which involves placing a catheter in the renal arteries but not delivering any radiofrequency energy. Participants in the placebo group will undergo a placebo procedure, which involves placing a catheter in the renal arteries but not delivering any radiofrequency energy. All participants will undergo a series of tests and procedures before and after the procedure, including blood tests, imaging studies, and questionnaires. The study will last for 12 months.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of the anti-PD-1 antibody, pembrolizumab, and the anti-CTLA-4 antibody, tremelimumab, in patients with advanced melanoma.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a multicenter, open-label, single-arm, phase II study. The study will enroll 100 patients with advanced melanoma who have received at least one prior systemic therapy. Patients will receive pembrolizumab 200 mg intravenously every 3 weeks and tremelimumab 75 mg intravenously every 4 weeks. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a novel, non-invasive, and non-pharmacological treatment for chronic low back pain (CLBP) using a wearable device that delivers a combination of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover trial. Participants will be randomized to receive either active or sham treatment for 2 weeks, followed by a 2-week washout period, and then crossover to the other treatment for 2 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be pain intensity, assessed using a visual analog scale (VAS). Secondary outcome measures will include disability, quality of life, and patient satisfaction.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a combination treatment of irinotecan liposome injection (S095013), oxaliplatin, levoisomer form of leucovorin (LLV), and 5‐Fluorouracil (5‐FU) in Japanese participants with metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas who have not previously received therapy. Methods: This was a single‐arm multicentre study conducted in Japan. Japanese participants with metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas who had not previously received therapy were enrolled. The participants received irinotecan liposome injection (S095013), oxaliplatin, LLV, and 5‐FU as a combination treatment. The primary endpoint was the objective response rate (ORR) according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) version 1.1. The secondary endpoints included progression‐free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and safety. Results: A total of 20 participants were enrolled in the study. The median age of the participants was 65 years (range, 43‐76 years), and 13 (65%) were male. The median number of prior systemic therapies was 1 (range, 0‐2). Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine if a behavioral intervention called Connect-Home Plus can improve the quality of life of persons with Alzheimer's disease and other dementias and their caregivers.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in two phases. In Phase 1, the investigators will conduct a pilot study to determine the feasibility of the intervention and to refine the intervention. In Phase 2, the investigators will conduct a randomized controlled trial to determine the efficacy of the intervention. The intervention will be delivered by trained community health workers (CHWs) who will visit the participants' homes to provide the intervention. The intervention will consist of 10 sessions over 10 weeks. The sessions will focus on improving the participants' quality of life and reducing caregiver burden. The sessions will also include education about Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.

The intervention is designed to improve the quality of life of patients with ADRD and their caregivers by providing a structured approach to transitional care. The intervention will be delivered in the skilled nursing facility and via telephone after discharge. It will introduce organizational structure to support delivery of transitional care processes, including the use of electronic health record (EHR) templates, Connect-Home Plus Toolkit, and staff training. The intervention will consist of two steps. In Step 1, SNF nurses, therapists, and social workers will develop a Transition Plan of Care and prepare the patient and caregiver to manage the illness and functional needs. In Step 2, a dementia caregiving specialist will make three calls to the patient's home within 30 days of discharge. The intervention will focus on key care needs such as home safety, symptom management, medication reconciliation, function and activity, and coordination of follow-up medical care.

This is a Phase 1/2, open-label, multicenter, dose-escalation and expansion study of NKT2152 in combination with palbociclib and sasanlimab in subjects with advanced clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC). The study will be conducted in two parts: Part 1: Dose Escalation and Part 2: Dose Expansion. Part 1 will evaluate the safety and tolerability of NKT2152 in combination with palbociclib and sasanlimab in subjects with advanced ccRCC. Part 2 will evaluate the efficacy and safety of NKT2152 in combination with palbociclib and sasanlimab in subjects with advanced ccRCC.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, multicenter, dose-escalation and dose-expansion study of NKT2152 in combination with palbociclib and sasanlimab in patients with advanced clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC). The study will be conducted in two parts: a dose-escalation phase and a dose-expansion phase. The dose-escalation phase will evaluate the safety and tolerability of NKT2152 in combination with palbociclib and sasanlimab in patients with advanced ccRCC. The dose-expansion phase will evaluate the safety and efficacy of NKT2152 in combination with palbociclib and sasanlimab in patients with advanced ccRCC who have progressed on prior anti-VEGF/VEGFR systemic therapy and one ICI.

The intervention is a 12-week exercise program. The exercise program consists of 12 weeks of 30-minute sessions, 3 times a week. The exercise program includes stretching, strengthening, and balance exercises.

Primary outcome measure
=================
The primary outcome measure is the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS). The UPDRS is a scale that measures the severity of Parkinson's disease symptoms. It includes items that assess motor function, activities of daily living, and non-motor symptoms. The UPDRS is a widely used and validated measure of Parkinson's disease severity.

Secondary outcome measures
=================
The secondary outcome measures are the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, the Berg Balance Scale (BBS), and the 6-minute walk test (6MWT). The TUG test measures the time it takes to stand up from a chair, walk 3 meters, turn around, walk back to the chair, and sit down. The BBS measures balance and falls risk. The 6MWT measures the distance walked in 6 minutes.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new formulation of 0.1% tacrolimus ointment in the treatment of atopic dermatitis. Methods: This was a randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, parallel‐group, multicenter study. Patients with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis were randomized to receive either 0.1% tacrolimus ointment or placebo twice daily for 4 weeks. The primary efficacy endpoint was the change in the Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI) score from baseline to week 4. Results: A total of 100 patients were randomized to receive either 0.1% tacrolimus ointment (n = 50) or placebo (n = 50). The mean change in the EASI score from baseline to week 4 was significantly greater in the tacrolimus ointment group than in the placebo group (‐11.0 vs. ‐4.0, P < 0.001). The mean change in the Investigator's Global Assessment (IGA) score from baseline to week 4 was also significantly greater in the tacrolimus ointment group than in the placebo group (‐1.0 vs. ‐0.3, P < 0.001). The incidence of adverse events was similar between the two groups. Conclusion: 0.1% tacrolimus ointment was effective and well tolerated in the treatment of atopic dermatitis.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine whether the use of a new ventilation method, called flow-controlled ventilation, is superior to the current standard of care, pressure-controlled ventilation, in patients undergoing robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine whether the use of a new ventilation method, called flow-controlled ventilation, is superior to the current standard of care, pressure-controlled ventilation, in patients undergoing robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery. The study will be conducted in a single-center, randomized, controlled, parallel-group, single-blinded trial. The study will enroll 100 patients undergoing robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery with a duration of expected ventilation of at least 90 minutes. The patients will be randomly assigned to receive either flow-controlled ventilation or pressure-controlled ventilation. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of postoperative pulmonary atelectasis, which will be assessed using chest X-rays taken within 24 hours after surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include the incidence of other postoperative complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, and mortality, as well as the length of hospital stay and the duration of mechanical ventilation.

The study will be conducted in a pragmatic, open-label, parallel design randomized controlled trial (RCT). The study will include 120 adult smokers who are seeking help to quit smoking. Participants will be randomized to receive either EC or NRT for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the 7-day point prevalence abstinence rate at the end of the 12-week intervention period. The study will also assess the cost-effectiveness of using EC compared to NRT in the Pakistani population.

The first study arm could be an active comparator arm, where participants receive Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT). The NRT used will be a combination therapy involving transdermal nicotine patches combined with faster-acting oral products like gum or lozenges. The strength of nicotine patches will range from 7 to 21 mg, and for gum or lozenges, the strength will be 1-4 mg. Participants will use a daily nicotine patch along with ad libitum use of the faster-acting lozenge to manage nicotine cravings. A 12-week supply of NRT will be provided. This arm represents the standard treatment for smoking cessation and allows us to compare the effectiveness of EC against a recognized and proven method.

For the second study arm, we can have an experimental arm where participants are randomized to receive Electronic Cigarettes (EC). Participants in this arm will be provided with an EC starter kit, including a personal vaping device with an integrated battery and three commonly used e-liquid flavors (tobacco, menthol, and fruit) with a nicotine concentration of 18-20 mg/ml. EC will be supplied for a total of 12 weeks. This arm allows us to evaluate the efficacy and safety of EC as a smoking cessation tool compared to NRT, and also assess the cost-effectiveness of using EC compared to NRT in the Pakistani population.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a 12‐week exercise program in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF). Methods: A total of 100 patients with CHF were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, which included aerobic and resistance training. The control group received standard medical care. The primary outcome was the change in peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak) from baseline to 12 weeks. Secondary outcomes included changes in functional capacity, quality of life, and biomarkers of cardiac function. Results: The exercise group showed a significant increase in VO2peak (1.1 ± 0.3 mL/kg/min, p < 0.001), 6‐minute walk distance (36 ± 10 m, p < 0.001), and quality of life scores (p < 0.05). The control group showed no significant changes in these outcomes. Conclusion: A 12‐week exercise program was effective in improving exercise capacity, quality of life, and cardiac function in patients with CHF.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a 12‐week, high‐intensity, home‐based exercise program in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF). Methods: A total of 100 patients with CHF were randomly assigned to either a control group (n = 50) or an exercise group (n = 50). The exercise group performed a 12‐week, high‐intensity, home‐based exercise program, consisting of aerobic and resistance exercises. The control group did not receive any exercise intervention. The primary outcome was the change in the 6‐minute walk test (6MWT) distance. Secondary outcomes included the change in the New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class, quality of life, and exercise capacity. Results: The exercise group showed a significant improvement in the 6MWT distance (p < 0.001), NYHA functional class (p < 0.001), and quality of life (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. The exercise group also showed a significant improvement in exercise capacity (p < 0.001). Conclusion: A 12‐week, high‐intensity, home‐based exercise program is effective in improving exercise capacity, functional capacity, and quality of life in patients with CHF.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the long-term safety, tolerability, and effectiveness of the combination therapy of Pozelimab and Cemdisiran in patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 3, open-label, single-arm, multicenter study to evaluate the long-term safety, tolerability, and effectiveness of the combination therapy of Pozelimab and Cemdisiran in patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). The study will enroll approximately 100 patients with PNH who have completed treatment in the parent study (R3918-PNH-2021 [NCT05133531]) and have a documented C5 polymorphism rendering them refractory to eculizumab or ravulizumab. Patients will receive subcutaneous administration of both Pozelimab and Cemdisiran every 4 weeks for up to 104 weeks. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the long-term safety and tolerability of the combination therapy. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the effectiveness of the combination therapy in terms of hemoglobin levels, transfusion requirements, and quality of life.

The study will be conducted in two phases: a pre-operative phase and a post-operative phase. During the pre-operative phase, patients will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: the intervention group, which will receive a 3D model of their kidney, and the control group, which will not receive a 3D model. The 3D model will be created using the patient's preoperative CT scan and will be used to educate the patient about the surgery and the anatomy of the kidney. The patient's anxiety level will be assessed using the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) before and after the intervention. During the post-operative phase, the patient's anxiety level will be assessed again using the STAI. The primary outcome of the study is the change in the patient's anxiety level from pre- to post-intervention. The secondary outcomes of the study are the patient's satisfaction with the 3D model and the surgeon's satisfaction with the 3D model.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the prevalence of and risk factors for post-operative delirium in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Post-operative delirium is a common complication of major abdominal surgery. It is associated with increased morbidity and mortality, and increased length of hospital stay. The incidence of post-operative delirium is 20-30% in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery. The risk factors for post-operative delirium are not well understood. The purpose of this study is to determine the prevalence of and risk factors for post-operative delirium in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a new method of intraoperative neuromonitoring (IONM) in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (THA). Methods: A total of 100 patients undergoing THA were randomly divided into two groups. Group A (n = 50) underwent IONM using a nerve stimulator (NS) and group B (n = 50) underwent IONM using a nerve stimulator and a nerve monitor (NM). The primary outcome was the incidence of postoperative neurological complications. The secondary outcomes were the duration of surgery, the amount of intraoperative blood loss, and the length of hospital stay. Results: The incidence of postoperative neurological complications was significantly lower in group A than in group B (0% vs. 10%, P = 0.048). The duration of surgery and the amount of intraoperative blood loss were significantly shorter in group A than in group B (120.0 ± 15.0 min vs. 135.0 ± 18.0 min, P = 0.001; 100.0 ± 20.0 mL vs. 120.0 ± 25.0 mL, P = 0.001). The length of hospital stay was significantly shorter in group A than in group B (4.0 ± 0.5 days vs. 4.5 ± 0.6 days, P = 0.001). Conclusion: The new method of IONM using a nerve stimulator and a nerve monitor is more effective than the conventional method of IONM using a nerve stimulator alone in patients undergoing THA.

I'm glad you agree. Now, let's summarize the full study arms we've designed:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Early cessation of sedation and TTM
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who will undergo early cessation of sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) after a cardiac arrest with a favorable EEG pattern.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves stopping sedation and TTM early, within 12 hours of identifying a favorable EEG pattern, and potentially weaning from mechanical ventilation if appropriate.
   - Reasoning: This arm is essential to assess the feasibility and safety of early weaning from ICU treatment in patients with a favorable EEG pattern. By comparing outcomes in this group to the standard care group, the study can determine if early cessation of sedation and TTM is a viable option for these patients.

2. No Intervention: Standard Care
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of patients who will receive standard care, including sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) for at least 24-48 hours post-cardiac arrest.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The control group will not undergo early cessation of sedation and TTM, as per standard care protocols.
   - Reasoning: This arm serves as a comparison group to evaluate the impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM in the experimental group. By having a control group receiving standard care, the study can determine if the experimental intervention leads to better outcomes compared to the standard approach. This arm helps establish the baseline for comparison and provides valuable insights into the potential benefits of early weaning from ICU treatment.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a 12‐week, high‐intensity, home‐based exercise program on the physical and psychological health of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: A total of 100 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either the exercise group (n = 50) or the control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week, high‐intensity, home‐based exercise program, while the control group received usual care. The primary outcome was the 6‐minute walk test (6MWT). Secondary outcomes included the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ), the COPD Assessment Test (CAT), the Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea scale, the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), and the EuroQol‐5 Dimensions‐5 Levels (EQ‐5D‐5L) questionnaire. Results: After 12 weeks, the exercise group showed significant improvements in the 6MWT (p < 0.001), SGRQ (p < 0.001), CAT (p < 0.001), mMRC (p < 0.001), HADS (p < 0.001), and EQ‐5D‐5L (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. Conclusion: A 12‐week, high‐intensity, home‐based exercise program was effective in improving the physical and psychological health of patients with COPD.

Methods: A total of 100 older adults were randomly assigned to three groups: an experimental group that performed aerobic exercise alone, an experimental group that performed a combination of aerobic and resistance exercises, and a control group that did not receive any intervention. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week aerobic exercise program can improve senior fitness, aerobic capacity, and intrinsic capacity in older adults. Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: A total of 100 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program consisting of aerobic and resistance exercises, while the control group did not receive any specific intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The exercise group showed significant improvements in the total SGRQ score (p < 0.001), as well as in the symptoms, activity, and impact domains (p < 0.001 for all). The control group showed no significant changes in the SGRQ score. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This randomized controlled trial was conducted on 60 patients with COPD who were referred to the pulmonary rehabilitation center of the Imam Reza Hospital in Mashhad, Iran, in 2019. The patients were randomly divided into two groups of exercise and control. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) before and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 64.2 ± 7.2 years, and the mean SGRQ score was 48.1 ± 10.2. After the intervention, the mean SGRQ score decreased from 48.1 ± 10.2 to 34.2 ± 10.2 in the exercise group and from 48.1 ± 10.2 to 46.2 ± 10.2 in the control group. The mean difference in the SGRQ score between the two groups was ‐4.0 ± 10.2 (p = 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study showed that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life (QoL) of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not. The QoL of the patients was evaluated using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) and the COPD Assessment Test (CAT) before and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 64.3 ± 7.1 years, and 50% of the patients were male. The mean SGRQ score was 42.1 ± 10.1 before the intervention and 35.1 ± 10.1 after the intervention in the exercise group, while it was 42.1 ± 10.1 before the intervention and 41.1 ± 10.1 after the intervention in the control group. The mean CAT score was 18.1 ± 5.1 before the intervention and 16.1 ± 5.1 after the intervention in the exercise group, while it was 18.1 ± 5.1 before the intervention and 17.1 ± 5.1 after the intervention in the control group. There was no significant difference in the SGRQ and CAT scores between the two groups after the intervention. Conclusion: The 12‐week exercise program did not significantly improve the QoL of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a new, non‐invasive, and edible material (fruit leather) on the reduction of the palatoglossal air space shadow error in panoramic radiography. Methods: This randomized, double‐blind, controlled clinical trial was conducted on 100 patients who were referred to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology, School of Dentistry, Shahid Beheshti University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran, from January to June 2019. The patients were randomly divided into three groups: control, fruit leather, and chewing gum strip. The palatoglossal air space shadow error was measured using the ImageJ software. The data were analyzed using the SPSS software (version 22). Results: The mean palatoglossal air space shadow error in the control, fruit leather, and chewing gum strip groups was 1.12 ± 0.51, 0.91 ± 0.49, and 0.89 ± 0.48, respectively. The mean palatoglossal air space shadow error in the fruit leather and chewing gum strip groups was significantly lower than that in the control group (P < 0.05). Conclusion: The use of fruit leather and chewing gum strip can reduce the palatoglossal air space shadow error in panoramic radiography.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of different strips on the reduction of the most common error in panoramic imaging, specifically the palatoglossal air space shadow. Methods: A total of 100 patients were randomly assigned to three groups: fruit leather on the tongue, chewing gum strip, and celluloid matrix group. The panoramic radiographs were taken before and after the intervention. The palatoglossal air space shadow was measured using the ImageJ software. The data were analyzed using the paired t‐test and one‐way ANOVA. Results: The mean palatoglossal air space shadow reduction was 1.15 ± 0.95 mm in the fruit leather group, 1.12 ± 0.93 mm in the chewing gum strip group, and 1.05 ± 0.91 mm in the celluloid matrix group. There was no significant difference in the reduction of the palatoglossal air space shadow among the three groups (p = 0.92). Conclusion: The use of different strips did not significantly reduce the palatoglossal air space shadow error in panoramic imaging.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a mobile health (mHealth) intervention, Take a Break, in promoting smoking cessation motivation among lower-motivated smokers in rural areas. The study will compare the intervention with a control group that receives nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) sampling only. The study will also explore the impact of the intervention on smoking cessation behaviors and outcomes.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in rural areas of the United States. Participants will be recruited through community-based organizations, healthcare providers, and social media platforms. Eligible participants will be adults aged 18-65 who smoke cigarettes and are not currently trying to quit. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two study arms: the experimental arm (Take a Break plus NRT sampling) or the control arm (NRT sampling only). The experimental arm will receive the Take a Break intervention, which includes motivational text messages, challenge quizzes, goal-setting, coping mini-games, and recognition & rewards. Participants in the control arm will only receive NRT lozenges for sampling. Both groups will be followed for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be smoking cessation motivation, assessed using the Motivation to Change Scale. Secondary outcome measures will include smoking cessation behaviors and outcomes, such as quit attempts, abstinence rates, and self-reported smoking reduction. The study will also explore the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention among participants.

Brief summary
=================
Asthma is a common respiratory condition that affects millions of people worldwide, including pregnant women. During pregnancy, asthma can worsen due to hormonal changes and increased airway sensitivity. Incentive spirometry is a simple and non-invasive technique that involves deep breathing exercises to improve lung function and reduce the risk of respiratory complications. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of incentive spirometry in improving asthma management in pregnant women. The study will include 30 pregnant women with asthma who will be randomly assigned to two groups: a control group that will receive standard treatment with inhaled glucocorticoids (pulmicort inhaler) and an experimental group that will receive the same treatment plus incentive spirometer treatment. The incentive spirometer program will be provided 3 days per week for six weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the change in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) from baseline to the end of the study. Secondary outcome measures will include the change in peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR), asthma control test (ACT) score, and the incidence of asthma exacerbations. The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of incentive spirometry in improving asthma management in pregnant women and may contribute to the development of evidence-based guidelines

Abstract:
Background: Obesity is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, and the prevalence of obesity‐related cardiomyopathy (ORCM) is increasing. Fibroblast growth factor‐21 (FGF21) is a hormone that regulates energy metabolism and has been shown to protect against heart dysfunction induced by a high‐fat diet. Canagliflozin, a sodium‐glucose cotransporter‐2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, has been shown to activate FGF21 expression. This study aimed to investigate the effects of Canagliflozin on the concentration of FGF21 and its downstream proteins in the liver and heart of patients with obesity‐related cardiomyopathy. Methods: This was a prospective, randomized, open‐label, controlled study. Patients with obesity‐related cardiomyopathy were randomly assigned to receive Canagliflozin 100mg daily for 1 month or no intervention. The primary outcome was the change in the concentration of FGF21 and its downstream proteins in the liver and heart. Results: A total of 20 patients were enrolled in the study, with 10 patients in each group. The mean age of the patients was 55.3±10.1 years, and the mean body mass index was 32.5±4.9 kg/m2. After 1 month of treatment, the concentration of FGF21 and its downstream proteins in the liver and heart significantly increased in the Canagliflozin group compared to the no intervention group (p<0.05). Conclusion: Canagliflozin treatment for 1 month significantly increased the concentration of FGF21 and its downstream proteins in the liver and heart of patients with obesity‐related cardiomyopathy. This study suggests that Canagliflozin may have a protective effect against heart dysfunction induced by a high‐fat diet.

Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of a new drug, called AZD1480, in patients with advanced solid tumors. AZD1480 is a drug that blocks a protein called CDK4/6, which is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells. The study will enroll patients with advanced solid tumors who have not responded to standard treatments or for whom no standard treatments are available. Patients will receive AZD1480 by mouth once daily for 21 days followed by 7 days off treatment. Treatment will continue until the disease progresses or unacceptable side effects occur.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase I, open-label, dose-escalation study of AZD1480 in patients with advanced solid tumors. The study will enroll patients with advanced solid tumors who have not responded to standard treatments or for whom no standard treatments are available. Patients will receive AZD1480 by mouth once daily for 21 days followed by 7 days off treatment. Treatment will continue until the disease progresses or unacceptable side effects occur. The primary objective of the study is to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of AZD1480. Secondary objectives include determining the safety and tolerability of AZD1480, assessing the pharmacokinetics of AZD1480, and evaluating the preliminary efficacy of AZD1480.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the diagnostic performance of shear wave elastography (SWE) and shear wave dispersive imaging (SWDI) in distinguishing benign from malignant breast lesions.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and early detection is crucial for successful treatment. Ultrasound is a widely used imaging modality for breast cancer screening and diagnosis. However, conventional ultrasound has limitations in distinguishing benign from malignant breast lesions. Shear wave elastography (SWE) and shear wave dispersive imaging (SWDI) are emerging ultrasound techniques that can provide quantitative information about tissue stiffness. These techniques have shown promising results in distinguishing benign from malignant breast lesions. In this study, we aim to evaluate the diagnostic performance of SWE and SWDI in distinguishing benign from malignant breast lesions. We will recruit 100 patients with breast lesions and perform SWE and SWDI on all patients. The results of SWE and SWDI will be compared with the histopathological results of the breast lesions. The diagnostic performance of SWE and SWDI will be evaluated using receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis.

Diagnostic Performance of Shear Wave Elastography and Shear Wave Dispersive Imaging in Distinguishing Benign From Malignant Breast Lesions

Breast Cancer

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the diagnostic performance of shear wave elastography (SWE) and shear wave dispersive imaging (SWDI) in the diagnosis of breast lesions. Methods: A total of 100 patients with breast lesions were enrolled in this study. SWE and SWDI were performed on all patients. The diagnostic performance of SWE and SWDI was evaluated by comparing the results with histopathological findings. Results: The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of SWE were 80.0%, 80.0%, and 80.0%, respectively. The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of SWDI were 80.0%, 80.0%, and 80.0%, respectively. The area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of SWE was 0.80, and the AUC of SWDI was 0.80. Conclusion: SWE and SWDI have similar diagnostic performance in the diagnosis of breast lesions.

The aim of this study was to investigate the clinical characteristics and outcomes of HFpEF patients with and without metabolic abnormalities and diastolic dysfunction. Results: The mean age of the patients was 68.6 ± 10.2 years, and 60% were female. The prevalence of metabolic abnormalities was 50%, and the prevalence of diastolic dysfunction was 70%. The patients with metabolic abnormalities had a higher prevalence of left ventricular hypertrophy, left atrial enlargement, and diastolic dysfunction. The study will enroll patients with HFpEF who are currently taking standard of care medications for their condition. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either AZD4635 or a placebo (a sugar pill that looks like the study drug but does not have any active ingredient) for 12 weeks. The study will enroll approximately 120 patients with HFpEF who are currently taking standard of care medications for their condition. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either AZD4635 or a placebo for 12 weeks. The study will evaluate the effects of AZD4635 on exercise capacity, quality of life, and other measures of heart function.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a novel, non-invasive, and non-pharmacological intervention for the treatment of chronic pain in patients with fibromyalgia. The intervention is a combination of a wearable device and a mobile application that provides real-time feedback on pain levels and activity levels. The study will be conducted in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive the wearable device and mobile application, while the control group will receive a sham device and mobile application. Both groups will be asked to use the device and mobile application for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be pain intensity, measured using a visual analog scale. Secondary outcome measures will include sleep quality, fatigue, and quality of life.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Fibromyalgia is a chronic pain condition that affects millions of people worldwide. It is characterized by widespread pain, fatigue, and sleep disturbances. Current treatments for fibromyalgia include medications, physical therapy, and cognitive-behavioral therapy. However, these treatments are often ineffective or have significant side effects. There is a need for new, non-invasive, and non-pharmacological treatments for fibromyalgia. The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a novel, non-invasive, and non-pharmacological intervention for the treatment of chronic pain in patients with fibromyalgia. The intervention is a combination of a wearable device and a mobile application that provides real-time feedback on pain levels and activity levels. The study will be conducted in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive the wearable device and mobile application, while the control group will receive a sham device and mobile application. Both groups will be asked to use the device and mobile application for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be pain intensity, measured using a visual analog scale.

Certainly! In Part A - Escalation, we will enroll patients who have either not received systemic therapy for advanced NSCLC or have received at least one line of systemic anticancer therapy for metastatic disease. This arm will help us assess the safety and tolerability of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab. We will start with a small number of patients and gradually escalate the dose of Tepotinib to evaluate any potential adverse effects and determine the optimal dosing regimen.

In Part B - Expansion, we will focus on patients with NSCLC and MET exon 14 skipping mutations who have not responded well to previous treatments. This arm aims to evaluate the efficacy of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab in a larger group of patients. By targeting patients with specific genetic mutations associated with NSCLC, we can assess the potential benefits of this targeted therapy approach in a population that may have limited treatment options.

In Part A - Escalation, patients will receive Tepotinib daily for three weeks. After three weeks, they will be given Pembrolizumab immunotherapy on a 21-day cycle alongside Tepotinib daily. Dose de-escalation of Tepotinib will be performed if necessary, based on the safety and tolerability assessments.

In Part B - Expansion, patients will receive the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab throughout the study. The safety run-in of Tepotinib will be tested in the first cycle, followed by the introduction of Pembrolizumab from cycle 2 onwards. This will allow us to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy in a larger group of patients with NSCLC and MET exon 14 skipping mutations.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of the Communication Bridge™ intervention for individuals with primary progressive aphasia (PPA) and their care partners. The intervention is a multi-component, participation-focused, dyadic intervention that is based on the Living with Aphasia: Framework for Outcome Measurement (A-FROM) and the Care Pathway Model specifically developed for individuals with primary progressive aphasia. The intervention will be delivered through a web-based application and will be tailored to the individual's needs and goals. The study will involve a single group assignment with no masking. The primary outcome measure will be the Aphasia Quality of Life (AQoL) questionnaire, which will be administered at baseline, post-intervention, and at 3-month and 6-month follow-ups. The secondary outcome measures will include the Communication Participation Scale (CPS), the Communication Activities of Daily Living (CADL) scale, and the Functional Communication Profile (FCP). The study will also include a qualitative component to gather feedback from participants and care partners on their experiences with the intervention.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a Phase 2/3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab versus cemiplimab alone in participants with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2/3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab versus cemiplimab alone in participants with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study will be conducted in two parts: Part 1 (Phase 2) and Part 2 (Phase 3). Part 1 will be a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-finding study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab versus cemiplimab alone in participants with advanced NSCLC. Part 2 will be a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, confirmatory study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab versus cemiplimab alone in participants with advanced NSCLC.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase 2/3, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multicenter Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Fianlimab in Combination With Cemiplimab Versus Cemiplimab Alone in Participants With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)

This is a Phase 2/3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab versus cemiplimab alone in participants with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2/3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab versus cemiplimab alone in participants with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study will consist of a Phase 2 dose-finding part and a Phase 3 part. In the Phase 2 part, participants will be randomized to receive fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab or placebo in combination with cemiplimab. In the Phase 3 part, participants will be randomized to receive fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab or cemiplimab alone. The primary objective of the Phase 2 part is to determine the recommended Phase 3 dose (RP2D) of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab. The primary objective of the Phase 3 part is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab versus cemiplimab alone in participants with advanced NSCLC.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase 2/3, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multicenter Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Fianlimab in Combination With Cemiplimab Versus Cemiplimab Alone in Participants With Advanced Non-Small

The primary outcome measure is overall survival (OS). OS is defined as the time from the start of treatment to the date of death from any cause.

Secondary outcome measures
=================
The secondary outcome measures are:
1. Progression-free survival (PFS): PFS is defined as the time from the start of treatment to the date of disease progression or death from any cause, whichever occurs first.
2. Objective response rate (ORR): ORR is defined as the percentage of patients who achieve a complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) according to the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) version 1.1.
3. Duration of response (DOR): DOR is defined as the time from the first documented response (CR or PR) to the first documented disease progression or death from any cause, whichever occurs first.
4. Safety and tolerability: Safety and tolerability will be assessed based on the incidence and severity of adverse events (AEs) and serious adverse events (SAEs) reported during the study.
